S3.T1.caption: TABLE I: IS and FID for centralized and FL approaches.
S3.T1.table:
\hlineB3 IS ↑↑\uparrow FID (train) ↓↓\downarrow FID (test) ↓↓\downarrow
CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN
Centralized 4.45 ± 0.12 4.15 ± 0.08 3.39 ± 0.04 10.30 7.93 13.18 11.70 8.92 13.13
FedAvg 3.69 ± 0.08 4.11 ± 0.12 3.07 ± 0.04 21.42 17.03 15.64 22.67 17.91 20.39
\hlineB3
references:
Figure 2 compares the quality of samples generated by the centralized and FL models across different datasets, while Table I reports their respective IS and FID metrics.
The results in Table I indicate a significant decline in the quality of samples generated by the FL global model compared to the centralized model.
However, upon visual examination of Fig. 2, it is observed that while samples from the centralized model may appear slightly more visually appealing for the CIFAR-10 dataset, those from the FL global model for the Fashion-MNIST and SVHN datasets can be relatively comparable, albeit with some degree of blurriness. These findings highlight the potential of training diffusion models in FL settings and the need for further exploration of improved FL designs for such training.

S3.T2.caption: TABLE II: IS and FID for different β𝛽\beta values.
S3.T2.table:
\hlineB3 IS ↑↑\uparrow FID (train) ↓↓\downarrow FID (test) ↓↓\downarrow
CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN
\hlineB3 β=0.1𝛽0.1\beta=0.1 3.65 ± 0.11 3.94 ± 0.09 3.14 ± 0.05 25.40 20.01 20.15 26.74 20.93 22.93
β=0.5𝛽0.5\beta=0.5 3.69 ± 0.08 4.11 ± 0.07 3.07 ± 0.04 21.42 17.03 15.64 22.67 17.91 20.39
β=5𝛽5\beta=5 3.66 ± 0.10 3.93 ± 0.08 3.12 ± 0.06 20.57 15.58 12.28 21.91 16.58 16.38
\hlineB3
references:
To investigate the effects of data heterogeneity on the quality of generated samples, we perform FL training with β𝛽\beta values of 0.10.10.1, 0.50.50.5, and 555.
Figure 3 illustrates the clients’ data distributions for each β𝛽\beta value, while Table II presents the IS and FID metrics of the generated samples.
Although the IS values are relatively comparable across the settings, the FID scores are more sensitive to data heterogeneity.
For each dataset, β=0.1𝛽0.1\beta=0.1 with the highest degree of data heterogeneity achieves the worst FID score, while β=5𝛽5\beta=5 achieves the best.
Overall, the quality of samples decreases as the degree of data heterogeneity increases, since local training tends to drift towards the local data distribution.
This highlights the need for further investigation into whether existing FL techniques for combating data heterogeneity can be applied to training diffusion models.

S3.T3.caption: TABLE III: IS and FID for different number of clients.
S3.T3.table:
\hlineB3 IS ↑↑\uparrow FID (train) ↓↓\downarrow FID (test) ↓↓\downarrow
CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN
\hlineB3 N=10𝑁10N=10 3.69 ± 0.08 4.11 ± 0.07 3.07 ± 0.04 21.42 17.03 15.64 22.67 17.91 20.39
N=30𝑁30N=30 3.02 ± 0.05 3.98 ± 0.11 2.95 ± 0.04 40.09 19.56 20.45 41.57 20.50 23.48
N=50𝑁50N=50 2.81 ± 0.07 4.21 ± 0.07 2.96 ± 0.04 48.69 35.61 23.76 50.23 36.46 26.46
\hlineB3
references:
We conduct experiments by varying the number of clients, setting N𝑁N to 101010, 303030, and 505050. It is important to note that the total amount of data samples is the same across all settings, and increasing the number of clients results in a more distributed data setup. While all clients participate in each communication round for N=10𝑁10N=10, we randomly sample 10 clients to participate for N=30𝑁30N=30 and N=50𝑁50N=50 settings, which reflects the practical FL scenarios where not all clients are available to participate in every round. As shown in Table III, the quality of the generated samples decreases as the number of clients increases, with N=50𝑁50N=50 having the worst FID scores compared to the other settings. In our experiment, we mainly aim to investigate the effects of data distributed over a large number of clients.
However, it is worth mentioning that in practice, more clients could lead to an improved quality of the FL global model due to the increased number of training data samples.

S3.T4.caption: TABLE IV: IS and FID scores for different local epochs.
S3.T4.table:
\hlineB3 IS ↑↑\uparrow FID (train) ↓↓\downarrow FID (test) ↓↓\downarrow
CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN CIFAR-10 Fashion-MNIST SVHN
\hlineB3 E=1𝐸1E=1 2.49 ± 0.04 4.01 ± 0.12 2.33 ± 0.03 79.79 36.36 48.16 81.60 37.31 52.85
E=5𝐸5E=5 3.69 ± 0.08 4.11 ± 0.07 3.07 ± 0.04 21.42 17.03 15.64 22.67 17.91 20.39
E=10𝐸10E=10 3.88 ± 0.12 3.95 ± 0.07 3.10 ± 0.04 18.22 12.78 11.73 19.51 13.75 17.31
\hlineB3
references: We also investigate the impact of the number of local epochs on model performance by setting E𝐸E to 111, 555, and 101010. The results are shown in Table IV, where we observe that the quality of generated samples generally improves with an increase in the number of local epochs. This suggests that longer training is beneficial for diffusion models with a large number of parameters. However, client devices in an FL environment typically have limited computing and communication resources. Therefore, increasing the number of local epochs can result in more computing burden on the clients. Moreover, this could also increase the risk of clients dropping out of the FL process without completing local training. Alternatively, we could decrease the number of local epochs while increasing the total number of communication rounds to achieve similar results. However, this approach would require significant communication resources for both the server and clients. Therefore, developing lightweight diffusion models that can facilitate training and deployment on edge devices is an important topic for future studies.

S3.T5.caption: TABLE V: IS and FID scores for the SARS-CoV-2 CT-scan dataset.
S3.T5.table:
\hlineB3 IS ↑↑\uparrow FID ↓↓\downarrow
\hlineB3 Centralized 1.72 ± 0.04 48.17
FedAvg 1.60 ± 0.03 134.98
\hlineB3
references: We report the IS and FID metrics in Table V, and Fig. 6 compares the generated samples with those from the source dataset. While Table V indicates that the centralized model generates samples with superior quality compared to the FL model, Fig. 6 shows that the generated samples from both models can be perceptually similar. This demonstrates a great potential of federated diffusion models for the medical field, where privacy concerns are prominent. However, it is important to mention that the generated samples have not yet been evaluated by a medical expert, which is necessary for further assessment.
